taskTitle: Plan and Manage Budget and Resources

quickScenarioChallenge.challengeSubtitle: Don't worry if you get it wrongâ€”that's how you learn!
quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: Your project has a $500K budget for 12 months. Three months in, you've spent $150K (30% of budget) but completed only 20% of the project scope. Your sponsor is asking for a forecast. What should you concern you MOST?
quickScenarioChallenge.question: What metric should trigger immediate escalation?

options.A: You're $50K over the monthly spending plan
options.B: Earned Value ($100K) is less than Actual Cost ($150K)â€”the project is losing money
options.C: You have 9 months left and 80% of work remainingâ€”the trend is unsustainable
options.D: The monthly burn rate is higher than originally planned

ahaDebrief.correctAnswer: B - Earned Value ($100K) vs. Actual Cost ($150K)

insights.explanation: Earned Value ($100K) represents work completed. Actual Cost ($150K) is what you spent. When AC > EV, you're overspending relative to progress. This is the core warning sign.
insights.pmbokSupport: EVM measures schedule and budget performance simultaneously

insights.explanation: CPI = EV/AC = $100K/$150K = 0.67. A CPI below 1.0 means you're getting $0.67 value per dollar spentâ€”unsustainable.
insights.pmbokSupport: CPI < 1.0 indicates cost overrun; requires corrective action

insights.explanation: At 3 months, this efficiency issue is detectable early. Waiting until month 6 or 9 makes recovery harder. Early warning = better options.
insights.pmbokSupport: Monitor performance regularly to enable proactive management

trapSection.explanation: Monthly variance is a symptom, not the root cause. EVM reveals the actual problem.

trapTable.violation: Confuses budget variance with earned valueâ€”doesn't show efficiency
trapTable.pmiValueBroken: Not using EVM to measure true performance

trapTable.violation: This is true BUT it's a symptom of the efficiency loss shown in B
trapTable.pmiValueBroken: Identifying consequence, not the core metric

trapTable.option: D - Burn rate higher than planned
trapTable.violation: True but doesn't compare spending to work accomplished

checklist: Is Earned Value (EV) less than Actual Cost (AC)?
Can the project recover with remaining budget and time?
patternRecognition.patternRule: When AC > EV (CPI < 1.0), immediately escalate and implement corrective action. Project is inefficient.

coreFramework.frameworkIntro: Managing budget and resources requires earned value thinking:

rows.action: Establish a cost baseline: approved budget for each work package, over time (with start/end dates).
keyQuestions: What's the total project cost estimate?
How is it distributed over time?
rows.examKeywords: Cost baseline, Approved budget, Budget allocation

rows.action: EV = % complete Ã— baseline cost. It measures work accomplished, not money spent.
keyQuestions: What % of work is actually done?
What's the budgeted cost of work performed?

rows.action: Calculate Cost Variance (CV = EV - AC) and CPI (EV/AC). Flag immediately if CPI < 1.0.
Use CPI to forecast final cost (EAC = BAC/CPI). Present options to sponsor.
keyQuestions: Will we exceed budget at current pace?
rows.examKeywords: Estimate at completion, Forecast, Options analysis

rows.action: Implement recovery plan: reduce scope, extend timeline, secure additional budget, increase efficiency.
rows.examKeywords: Corrective action, Scope adjustment, Resource reallocation

rows.action: Report EV metrics in regular status. Escalate when CPI drops or EAC exceeds budget.
rows.examKeywords: Status reporting, Trend analysis, Stakeholder communication

pmbokConnection.quote: Use earned value management to measure schedule and budget performance simultaneously

secondScenario.scenarioStory: Your project has a cost baseline of $1M over 12 months. At month 6: Planned Value (PV) = $500K, Earned Value (EV) = $450K, Actual Cost (AC) = $500K. The sponsor asks if the project is over budget.
secondScenario.question: What's your answer?

options.A: Yes, we're over budgetâ€”AC equals PV, meaning we've spent our planned amount
options.B: No, we're on budgetâ€”AC equals the amount we should have spent
options.C: We're behind schedule (EV < PV) but on budget (AC = PV), but this is unsustainable if efficiency doesn't improve
options.D: No, because EV is only slightly less than ACâ€”we're close enough

quotes.text: Earned Value is magic. It tells you three things at once: Are you on schedule? Are you on budget? Can you predict the final cost? All from one metric.
quotes.author: Andrew Ramdayal

quotes.text: The Cost Performance Index (CPI) is the most critical efficiency metric. CPI < 1.0 demands immediate action.
quotes.author: PMI

fieldInsights.title: EV Catches Early Problems
fieldInsights.insight: Monthly budget variance can hide efficiency loss. EV compares work done to money spent, revealing inefficiencies weeks before traditional budgeting.

fieldInsights.title: Forecast Early, Act Faster
fieldInsights.insight: EAC (Estimate at Completion) = BAC/CPI. Calculate it monthly. If EAC exceeds sponsor's budget, you have options to explore NOW.

story.title: Managing the Mountain Expedition Budget
story.narrative: You're planning a high-altitude expedition and must manage supplies carefully...

scenes.visual: ðŸ’° BASELINE supplies before the climb
scenes.description: You plan: 200 meals, 500 meters of rope, 100 oxygen bottles for the 12-week expedition. This is your budget baseline.

scenes.visual: ðŸ“Š UNDERSTAND what work is actually done
scenes.description: Three weeks in, you've reached Base Camp 2 (30% of the climb). Your baseline said you'd have 60 meals left. You've used 65 meals. EV says: '30% up the mountain' but AC shows you spent more supplies than expected.
Cost Variance: You spent more supplies (AC) than your progress deserved (EV). CPI = 0.92. You're getting only 92% value per supply item. Red flag.
At this rate (CPI = 0.92), you'll need 217 meals total, not 200. You won't have enough. EAC = 200/0.92 = 217 meals.
Options: Reduce climb (scope cut), turn back early (schedule), get resupply (more budget), or increase efficiency (rest climbers, lighter loads). Act now.

scenes.visual: ðŸ“ˆ TRACK daily and report weekly
scenes.description: Each day: Record supplies used vs. altitude gained. Each week: Show sponsor updated EAC. Trends matter more than single days.

story.moral: Budget management is like supply planning: **B**aseline your resources, **U**nderstand work completed, **D**etect when spending outruns progress, **G**et forecasts early, **E**xecute recovery, **T**rack relentlessly.
